questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient has hypertension and hypokalemia. His blood pressure is consistently elevated despite being on multiple antihypertensive medications. Laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma aldosterone concentration and suppressed plasma renin activity. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an adrenal adenoma. Which is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for this patient's condition?
Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of central diabetes insipidus?

A 68-year-old patient presents with symptoms of lethargy, nausea, and muscle cramps. laboratory tests reveal hyponatremia and plasma hypoosmolality. He has a history of lung cancer and was recently started on selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for depression. He is diagnosed with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). Which of the following statements regarding the management of SIADH is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Fluid restriction to less than 800ml/day is the first-line treatment for Mild to Moderate SIADH.

options.label: B
options.text: Severe SIADH is corrected with administration of 100 ml iv bolus of 3% NaCl

options.label: C
options.text: Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH

options.label: D
options.text: Demeclocycline and lithium can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate SIADH.

questions.correct_answer: C. Targeted sodium correction should be >1mEq/L per hour in case of severe SIADH
questions.explanation:
Severity of SIADH

Symptoms

Management

Mild

Asymptomatic, Mild lethargy, nausea

Fluid Restriction

Moderate

Pronounced Lethargy, Confusion, Cramps, Nausea and Vomiting

Fluid Restriction, Loop Diuretics, Vasopressin Antagonists(VAPTANS), Demeclocycline, Lithium

Severe

Severe symptoms (e.g., severe confusion, seizures, coma)

Hypertonic saline, fluid restriction, Vasopressin Antagonist

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement with respect to vasopressin inhibitors?

options.label: A
options.text: Conivaptan is used only as an intravenous formulation for hospitalised patients of hypovolemic/euvolemic hyponatremia.

options.label: B
options.text: Tolvaptan is given a black box warning and is intended to be given under close monitoring of serum Na+

options.label: C
options.text: Osmotic demyelination syndrome is one of the serious adverse effects of the usage of vasopressin antagonists.

options.label: D
options.text: Tolvaptan is a non-selective V1/V2 antagonist, while conivaptan is a selective V2 antagonist

questions.correct_answer: D. Tolvaptan is a non-selective V1/V2 antagonist, while conivaptan is a selective V2 antagonist

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a history of bed-wetting three to four times a week. The child has no significant medical history and physical examination is normal. Which of the following is an incorrect statement with respect to initial management for nocturnal enuresis in this child?

options.label: A
options.text: The drug of choice for nocturnal enuresis is intranasal desmopressin, administered at bedtime.

options.label: B
options.text: Primary nocturnal enuresis is the most common type where the child has never developed bladder control.

options.label: C
options.text: Initial management, in this case, is reducing water intake in the evening and doing bladder exercises.

options.label: D
options.text: Allergic reactions similar to urticaria or anaphylaxis can occur due to desmopressin administration.

questions.correct_answer: A. The drug of choice for nocturnal enuresis is intranasal desmopressin, administered at bedtime.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient, previously operated on for pituitary adenoma, was diagnosed with post-operative central diabetes insipidus. All of the following are true regarding the drug of choice for this patient, except?

options.label: A
options.text: The drug acts on V1 Receptor located in renal tubules

options.label: B
options.text: The preferred route is intranasal, as the drug is metabolised by trypsin in the gut

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral oedema can occur as a serious adverse effect of this drug

options.label: D
options.text: The drug is contraindicated in patients with acute renal failure

questions.correct_answer: A. The drug acts on V1 Receptor located in renal tubules
questions.explanation:
Receptor Type

G Subtype

Location

Actions

V1 (V1a)

Gq

Vascular smooth muscle, liver, CNS

Vasoconstriction, glycogenolysis, platelet aggregation, GIT smooth muscle constriction

V2

Gs

Renal collecting ducts

Increase water reabsorption

V3 (V1b)

Gq

Anterior pituitary, Pancreas, Adrenal Medulla

Release of ACTH

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of alcoholic cirrhosis presents with progressively worsening abdominal distention, decreased urine output, and swelling in his legs. On examination, his abdomen is tense and distended with caput medusa and ascites, and his chest shows spider angioma. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum creatinine levels. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this patient?

A 7-year-old child presents with persistent bedwetting despite implementing various lifestyle modifications, such as reducing fluid intake before bedtime and establishing a regular toileting schedule. Which of the following would be the appropriate drug of choice for this child?
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin receptor type

G Protein

Second messenger

Effect

Location

V1 (V1A)

Gq type

Increase IP3/DAG

Vasoconstriction, Increase BP.

It can be used in the treatment of shock.

Smooth muscle cells of blood vessels.

V2

Gs type

Increase cAMP

Increases vWF and Factor 8 (present in endothelial cells of blood vessels and nephron)

Increases aquaporin II on collecting ducts (Reabsorb water from urine)

V3 (V1B)

Gq type

Increase IP3/DAG

Increases ACTH and endorphins (stress hormone)

Present in brain neurons (a neuropeptide)

Property

Terlipressin

Felypressin

Desmopressin

Receptor

V1 agonist

V1 agonist

V2 agonist

Administration

Injections only

Injections only

Orally, Nasally

Uses

Control bleeding in esophageal varices

Add-on to local anaesthetic

Treatment of Hemophilia A.

 

Hepatorenal syndrome (DOC)

 

Epinephrine alternative

Nocturnal enuresis (bed wetting).

 

Resistant shock

 

Neurogenic diabetes insipidus (DOC).

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents following a severe head injury. On examination, the patient is unconscious with signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP). A CT scan reveals significant cerebral oedema and brain mass effect. The patient is scheduled for an emergency neurosurgery. Which medication is most appropriate for reducing cerebral oedema before and after the surgery in this patient?

A 70-year-old female with chronic heart failure is being treated with a diuretic to manage her symptoms of fluid overload. Recently, she has started to experience hearing loss and ringing in her ears. On reviewing her medications, which class of diuretics is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism of action

Examples

Clinical uses

Side effects

1. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Option C)

Inhibit carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the proximal tubule, decreasing bicarbonate reabsorption

Acetazolamide, Methazolamide

Angle closure Glaucoma, Altitude sickness

Metabolic acidosis, Hypokalemia, hyperammonemia

2. Loop diuretics (Option D)

Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle

Furosemide, Bumetanide

Acute pulmonary edema, Chronic heart failure, Hypercalcemia

Hypokalemia, Ototoxicity, Metabolic alkalosis,

Hyperglycemia,

Hyperuricemia

3. Thiazide diuretics (Option A)

Inhibit sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule

Hydrochlorothiazide, Chlorthalidone

Hypertension, Edema

Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia,

Hyperglycemia ,Hyperuricemia

, metabolic alkalosis.

4. Potassium-sparing

Inhibit sodium channels in the distal nephron or block aldosterone receptors

Spironolactone, Amiloride

Heart failure, Hyperaldosteronism

Hyperkalemia, Gynecomastia (for Spironolactone)

,metabolic acidosis

5. Osmotic diuretics (Option B)

Increase osmolarity of the glomerular filtrate, inhibiting water reabsorption.

Mannitol, Glycerin

Cerebral oedema, Acute glaucoma

Dehydration, Electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: A patient on long-term lithium therapy visits with complaints of frequent urination and increased thirst. He was diagnosed with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) based on urine analysis and plasma ADH levels. He was prescribed a combination of amiloride and hydrochlorothiazide. What is the reason for the use of thiazide diuretics in nephrogenic DI?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules

options.label: B
options.text: Thiazides directly increase the sensitivity of the kidneys to ADH.

options.label: C
options.text: Thiazides help to increase lithium excretion, reducing its nephrotoxic effects.

options.label: D
options.text: Thiazides decrease the risk of hypokalemia when used with amiloride.

questions.correct_answer: A. Thiazides reduce urine output by increasing free water absorption in proximal tubules
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism

Thiazide diuretics

Induce mild volume depletion → ↑ proximal tubular reabsorption of water → ↓ urine output

Amiloride

Blocks ENaC channels in collecting ducts → ↓ lithium uptake → renal protection

Lithium

Causes nephrogenic DI by damaging ADH-sensitive pathways in collecting ducts

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to thiazides and loop diuretics?

options.label: A
options.text: Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in hypertensive patients with low GFR.

options.label: B
options.text: Thiazides cause indirect vasodilatation by prostaglandin release, unlike loop diuretics

options.label: C
options.text: Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in patients with osteoporosis

options.label: D
options.text: Thiazides will not cause hypokalemia, unlike loop diuretics

questions.correct_answer: C. Thiazides are preferred over loop diuretics in patients with osteoporosis

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic hypertensive who hasn't taken his medication in the past three days presents with an acute severe headache, blurry vision, palpitations, and diaphoresis. On examination, blood pressure is 240/140 mm Hg. Which of the following is the ideal drug of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Diuretic Type

Uses

Thiazide - Chlorothiazide (Option B)

 

HTN (effective in low-grade HTN)

It is not for acute fluid overload but can be used as an adjunct

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors - Acetazolamide (Option C)

 

Glaucoma, altitude sickness

Not for acute hypertension or fluid overload

Osmotic Diuretics - Mannitol (Option D)

Reducing intracranial pressure, acute renal failure

questions.text: A patient with chronic renal failure and resistant oedema was treated with a drug that alleviated the oedema. However, increasing doses were needed over time. Although the drug remained effective, the patient developed involuntary hand twitching and perioral numbness. Which class of drug was given?

A 32-year-old mountain climber presents to the base camp complaining of severe headache, nausea, and fatigue after ascending rapidly to a high altitude. On examination, his respiratory rate is increased, and arterial blood gas analysis shows decreased partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2). Given the Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS) suspicion, acetazolamide is administered to alleviate symptoms. Which of the following best describes acetazolamide's primary mechanism of action in treating AMS?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Change

High altitude effect

↓ PaO₂ → ↑ ventilation → ↓ PaCO₂ → Respiratory alkalosis

Acetazolamide effect

Inhibits carbonic anhydrase → ↑ HCO₃⁻ excretion

Acid–base result

Metabolic acidosis

Clinical outcome

Stimulates respiration, ↓ AMS symptoms

questions.text: All of the following are preferred uses of acetazolamide, except?
questions.explanation:
Indications

Mechanism of action

Medication and uses

Glaucoma (Option D)

MOA: Reduces aqueous humor secretion from ciliary cells
  • Eye Drops: Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide
    • Use: Primary open-angle glaucoma
  • IV Drugs: Acetazolamide
    • Use: Emergency treatment for acute congestive glaucoma

Alkalinisation of Urine

MOA: excretion of bicarbonate

 

Side Effects:

  • Higher risk of alkaline renal stones
  • Increased risk of calcium phosphate stones

Treatment:

  • Thiazide diuretics: Reduce calcium excretion
  • Useful for acidic drug poisoning
  • Effective against acidic kidney stones, including uric acid stones (Option A) and cystine stones (associated with homocystinuria)

Metabolic Acidosis in Blood (Option B)
  • Condition: Elevated levels of H+ ions in the blood
  • Treatment: Acetazolamide is the drug of choice for mountain sickness (especially HAPE-High Altitude Pulmonary Edema)

Epilepsy

  • Suppresses the activity of neurons
  • Acetazolamide was earlier used for epilepsy

Periodic

muscle paralysis
  • Imbalance of potassium ion in blood
  • Occurs due to Hyperkalemia, Hypokalemia
  • Acetazolamide is used in periodic muscle paralysis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who has been treated for glaucoma comes with complaints of muscle weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. Laboratory tests reveal significant hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which class of diuretics is most likely responsible for these symptoms, considering the maximum loss of potassium?
questions.explanation:
Type

Mechanism of action

Examples

Clinical uses

Side effects
  1. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (Option C)

Inhibit carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the proximal tubule, decreasing bicarbonate reabsorption

Acetazolamide, Methazolamide

Glaucoma, Altitude sickness

Metabolic acidosis, Hypokalemia
  1. Loop diuretics (Option D)

Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle

Furosemide, Bumetanide

Acute pulmonary edema, Chronic heart failure, Hypercalcemia

Hypokalemia, Ototoxicity, Metabolic alkalosis,

Hyperglycemia,

Hyperuricemia
  1. Thiazide diuretics (Option A)

Inhibit sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule

Hydrochlorothiazide, Chlorthalidone

Hypertension, Edema

Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia,

Hyperglycemia

Hyperuricemia
  1. Potassium-sparing

Inhibit sodium channels in the distal nephron or block aldosterone receptors

Spironolactone, Amiloride

Heart failure, Hyperaldosteronism

Hyperkalemia, Gynecomastia (for Spironolactone)
  1. Osmotic diuretics (Option B)

Increase osmolarity of the glomerular filtrate, inhibiting water reabsorption.

Mannitol, Glycerin
